Award.AwardTitle: 2018 World Congress of Biomechanics: Undergraduate Student Support from the Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering and Biotransport (SB3C) Foundation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support student activities at the 2018 Summer Biomechanics, Biotransport and Bioengineering Conference (SB3C2018) being held in conjunction with the 2018 World Congress of Biomechanics (WCB2018) in Dublin, Ireland, on July 6-11, 2018. The SB3C meetings, and their predecessor SBC meetings, are generally considered the premiere annual meetings for biomechanics. The quadrennial World Congress of Biomechanics is the world's largest conference on biomechanics. The primary purpose of the meeting is to promote state-of-the-art research, collaboration, and international scientific discourse in the broad field of bioengineering with focus on biomechanics, biotechnology, biotransport, biomaterials, tissue engineering, rehabilitation and design. The organizing committee for WCB18 and SB3C2018 is drawn from individuals in academia and the industry with significant experience in running the previous summer meetings. The meeting and its precursor meetings have traditionally provided a high-quality, multidisciplinary biomedical engineering event since the early 90's and contributed to training many generations of academics and researchers. Notably, the summer meetings series has, since its inception, prioritized the integration of students into the meeting to support their professional development and future connection to the biomechanics, biotransport and bioengineering research community. For many years, students have made up more than 50% of attendees and presenters at SB3C meetings. In addition to the direct impact this conference will have on the mainstream bioengineering community, it serves an important cross-fertilization role, since attendees are drawn from a very broad range of disciplines beyond biomechanics .

The aims of the project are to sponsor 20 travel fellowships for females and under-represented minorities; to support a Diversity Mentorship event to connect students from underrepresented groups with academic mentors; and to sponsor the prestigious Student Paper Competition by covering the meeting registration costs of the top 20 submissions to each of the BS and MS competitions. Student travel fellowships will be targeted at students who have just completed their junior year, which will allow them to network and explore graduate school options. These students typically have not advanced enough in their undergraduate research to obtain institutional support for conference travel. Finalists and winners in the student paper competition can add this information to their resumes, and the competition provides an opportunity for students to develop as researchers and is a significant career boost, enhancing retention of the most talented students and providing role models for all student attendees. Through the technical proceedings and conference web site, information presented at the meeting will be available to multiple societies and to the public at large. Further, the conference has historically had, and is expected to continue to have more than 50 percent of the attendees being students and postdoctoral fellows and more than 25 percent female attendees. For the second time, the organization committee has been extended to include a Diversity Chair. Through the travel fellowships and associated workshops, the PI plans to establish this meeting as the "go to" conference for female and under-represented minority attendees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diversity Travel Awards

Purpose:   To increase the diversity of the WCB 2018 meeting through targeted diversity travel awards for both undergraduate (NSF support) and graduate (NIH support with supplementation by NSF support) students. 

Notes from this year:  

  • funded exclusively registration costs and cost of DMME lunches
  • only funded students at US institutions
  • did not fund postdoctoral fellows or faculty
  • 8 of the awardees declined registration reimbursement as they received reimbursement as an ASME Student Paper Competition participant/finalist, all of these folks still participated in the DMME
  • Submission handled through online google form
  • Emails to large list serves sent out in late Jan early Feb letting folks know that there may be opportunities to fund registration of URM grads/undergrads
  • Email sent in early March to large list serves letting faculty know that deadlines have been set for applications to the Diversity Travel Awards (March 20th for grads, May 14th for UGs)

 

Applicants: 81 applicants (up from 59 in 2017)

Awardees: Total of 75 awardees (9 undergraduate, 66 graduate)…..up from 28 in 2017

39 institutions (24 in 2017)

62 female, 13 male (20 female and 8 male in 2017)

23 Hispanic (11 in 2017)

4 African American (24 in 2017)

5 Identified as LGBTQ

3 with a disability

66 US Citizens, 9 non-US citizens (all enrolled at US institutions)

Diversity Mentor-Mentee Event (DMME)

Purpose:   To provide mentoring and networking opportunities through creation of mentor-mentee conversations occurring individually over an informal get together (lunch/coffee). 

Notes from this year:   All Diversity Travel Awardees were required to participate in the DMME, which was a lunch or coffee organized individually by a faculty mentor and 2 to 3 student mentees.  Students were sent an email on 6/4/2018 and asked to fill out an online form ranking their interest in numerous discussion topics (listed below) and this data was used to group these students into groups of common interest.  The assigned faculty mentor was then made aware of the high ranking topics of discussion for their group of mentees and was asked to prepare for these conversations prior to their lunch. Care was taken to ensure the pool of faculty mentors was diverse.

Attendees:   All 75 of the Diversity Travel Awardees participated in the DMME and there were 27 faculty mentors that were recruited and participated in this event.

Demographics:  

Student demographics are listed above in the Diversity Travel Awardee section. There were 14 male and 13 female faculty mentors involved in the DMME.

Topics students were asked to rank to guide discussions over lunch

  • Optimizing your time (grad student, postdoc, faculty member)        
  • Finding the right postdoctoral position          
  • Diversity in the workforce - academia and industry  
  • Tips for finding an industrial job        
  • Tips for finding an academic job       
  • Life as a faculty member       
  • Achieving sustainable work/family balance  
  • Dealing with imposter syndrome       
  • Working past barriers of underrepresentation in gender and ethnicity         
  • Negotiation skills and tips

Results from Survey of Students Post DMME Event

A survey of students participating in the DMME was sent on 7/26/18 (a copy of this questionnaire is provided below).  The purpose of the survey was to quantitatively assess if the DMME event had a significant impact on the career development of DMME student participants in four areas: A) increasing their interest in the field of biomechanics and bioengineering; B) increasing their interest in pursuing a career in biomedical research; C) preparing them to meet their future career goals; and D) broadening their professional network.  51 of the 75 DMME student participants responded to this survey (68% response rate). The scores for student responses (1-Decreased significantly to 5-Increased significantly) in the four career development categories listed above (A-D) were 3.75 +/- 0.66, 4.29 +/- 0.73, 4.31 +/- 0.68, 4.27 +/- 0.57, respectively (p<0.001 in a one sample t-test comparing these numbers to a score of 3 indicating ‘Did not change’). These results suggest that the DMME was a resounding success in promoting the career development of students from under-represented groups in bioengineering.
